docs.lead_paragraph: As the House moved toward climactic votes on legislation to remake the health care system, the Congressional Budget Office said Monday that middle-income families might be required to pay 15 percent to 18 percent of their income on insurance premiums and co-payments under the proposal. Democrats cited the figures as evidence that the legislation would reduce premiums for many low- and middle-income families who currently lack affordable coverage.

headline.main: Democrats Say House Bill Cuts Premiums for Many

docs.abstract: Congressional Budget Office says middle-income families might be required to pay 15 percent to 18 percent of their income on insurance premiums and co-payments under House's health care proposal; Democrats cite figures as evidence that legislation would reduce premiums for many low- and middle-income families who currently lack affordable coverage; House Republicans are drafting alternative that they say would be less costly but cover fewer people; photo (M)
docs.snippet: House Republicans were drafting an alternative health care plan that they said would be much less costly. They acknowledged that it would cover fewer people.

byline.original: By ROBERT PEAR and CARL HULSE

docs.lead_paragraph: The House is moving toward a health care showdown later in the week, and if comments by Representative Virginia Foxx are any indication, things may get a little rough. As the House convened Monday afternoon, Ms. Foxx, a North Carolina Republican, sharply criticized the proposal Democrats are trying to bring to the floor for a vote by the weekend, hitting it as potentially using tax dollars to pay for abortions, among other things.
docs.abstract: Rep Virginia Foxx, North Carolina Republican, sharply criticizes Democratic health care proposal as more fearful than terrorist threat; photo (S)
docs.snippet: The House is moving toward a health care showdown later in the week, and if comments by Representative Virginia Foxx are any indication, things may  get a little rough.     As the House convened Monday afternoon, Ms. Foxx, a North Carolina...

docs.lead_paragraph: Public health experts worried about the spread of the H1N1 flu are raising concerns that workers who deal with the public, like waiters and child care employees, are jeopardizing others by reporting to work sick because they do not get paid for days they miss for illness. Tens of millions of people, or about 40 percent of all private-sector workers, do not receive paid sick days, and as a result many of them cannot afford to stay home when they are ill. Even some companies that provide paid sick days have policies that make it difficult to call in sick, like giving demerits each time someone misses a day.
docs.snippet: About 40 percent of private-sector workers do not receive paid sick days, and many cannot afford to miss work.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERACTIVE FEATURE Six men and women talk about their experiences with the nation's patchwork health insurance system, which can often frustrate and baffle. nytimes.com/health
docs.snippet: INTERACTIVE FEATURE Six men and women talk about their experiences with the nation's patchwork health insurance system, which can often frustrate and baffle.      nytimes.com/health

docs.lead_paragraph: Pauline McAreavy voted for President Obama. From the moment she first saw him two years ago, she was smitten by his speeches and sold on his promise of change. She switched parties to support him in the Iowa caucuses, donated money and opened her home to a pair of young campaign workers. But by the time she received a fund-raising letter last month from the Democratic National Committee, a sense of disappointment had set in. She returned the solicitation with a handwritten note, saying, ''Until I see some progress and he lives up to his promises in Iowa, we will not give one penny.''

headline.main: In Iowa, Euphoria Gives Way to Doubts About Obama

docs.abstract: Interviews with voters across Iowa offer window into how Pres Obama's standing, one year after election, has leveled off, particularly among independents and Republicans, who believed he would be able to break away from usual politics; Obama still has generally strong approval ratings and opportunities that come with Democratic majority in Congress but public opinion remains in flux; voters Candi Schmieder and Pauline McAreavy comment; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The president’s standing has fallen in the state that jump-started his campaign, especially among independents and Republicans.

docs.lead_paragraph: The health care bill that the full House may take up later this week is much tougher on the drug industry than what the Senate is considering. And that could prove one of the challenges for lawmakers when the legislation eventually reaches a House-Senate conference committee. The Senate health committee did not address drug pricing, but the Senate Finance Committee's version includes a deal, supported by the White House, that aims to save Medicare enrollees and the government $80 billion over 10 years.
docs.abstract: Senate Finance Committee version of health care proposal includes deal that aims to save Medicare enrollees and government $80 billion over decade; House bill, in comparison, would cost drug industry about $140 billion over decade (S)
docs.snippet: The health care bill that the full House may take up later this week is much tougher on the drug industry than what the Senate is considering. And that could prove one of the challenges for lawmakers when the legislation eventually reaches a...

docs.lead_paragraph: Tim Fernholz, left, of The American Prospect and Matt Lewis of Politics Daily debate whether the public option will be in the final Senate bill.
docs.snippet: Tim Fernholz, left, of The American Prospect and Matt Lewis of Politics Daily debate whether the public option will be in the final Senate bill.

docs.lead_paragraph: Much of the debate about health care reform focuses on people who don't have insurance. But as Karen Barrow explores during the latest Patient Voices series, even people with insurance coverage are struggling with bills, confusing policies and red tape.

headline.main: Patient Voices: Coping With and Without Insurance

docs.abstract: The Senate and the House are moving toward completion of their respective health care bills, but many of the reforms under consideration would not take effect until 2013. Until then, many Americans will continue to live with a patchwork insurance system that often frustrates and baffles them. Here, six men and women share their experiences.
docs.snippet: The Senate and the House are moving toward completion of their respective health care bills, but many of the reforms under consideration would not take effect until 2013. Until then, many Americans will continue to live with a patchwork insurance...

docs.lead_paragraph: Even as the Senate and the House move toward completion of their respective health care bills, many Americans continue to struggle with an insurance system they often find baffling and frustrating. In the latest installment of "Patient Voices" by the multimedia producer Karen Barrow, six men and women talk about the difficult choices they must make in seeking and paying for health care. Listen to Patient Voices and share your thoughts in the comments section.

headline.main: Coping With, and Without, Health Insurance

docs.abstract: Six Americans share their experiences with health insurance.
docs.snippet: Six Americans share their experiences with health insurance.

docs.lead_paragraph: It was about this time last year that all eyes were on Barack Obama, then the Democratic presidential nominee, and his Republican opponent, Senator John McCain. This week, all eyes are on a few off-year governors' and Congressional contests whose results could serve as a litmus test for the 2010 midterm elections.
docs.abstract: Elections all around offer a glimpse into how voters will respond to Democrats' leadership in 2010 mid-term elections.
docs.snippet: Elections all around offer a glimpse into how voters will respond to Democrats' leadership in 2010 mid-term elections.
